object match
body: When you run `_.find` on a collection with a `props`, it checks if an object satisfies the key values in props. Is there any way to just check if a specific object matches?

title: Graph functions
body: I think it would be awesome if there were functions like BFS or DFS for searching trees or graphs. It would also be really cool if they were composable with other functions like `_.where`, `_.find`, and `_.reduce`.

title: Lodash CSP build
body:
Is there a CSP safe build of lodash?
Currently the `_.template` function doesn't work because chrome throw  :

```
Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script in the following Content Security Policy directive: "default-src 'self'". Note that 'script-src' was not explicitly set, so 'default-src' is used as a fallback
```

title: [suggestion] [docs] Colour of Section Headers
body: I recently noticed that the documentation had had its colour theme changed. I've tried to work with it for a few hours, but the purple colour of the section header keeps distracting the eyes away from the actual documentation. Can it be changed to something more neutral?

title: Created `concatAll` alias for `flatten`
body:
RxJS used the method `concatAll` instead of `flatten`. See https://github.com/Reactive-Extensions/RxJS/blob/master/doc/api/core/operators/concatall.md

It would be convenient to have this alias.

title: _.omit copies enumerable properties from prototype chain as well
body:
I'm not sure whether this is expected behavior, but if so it would be nice to have this behavior documented.

`_.clone` only copies enumerable own properties, while `_.pick` and `_.omit` copy enumerable properties from the prototype as well. This is rather inconsistent IMO, and should at least be documented.

title: _.omit does not convert integer property names to strings
Can't remove lodash directory in Windows
body: Yes some of us have to work on Windows where it can't handle very very long file names. We use a bunch of node modules but lodash has caused us a lot of trouble when we want to delete or move directories. Unfortunately for such a popular library the problem is almost inevitable. So here is the windows error message: And this is an example of how nested the directory structure is: Note: the last directory is not the end. Windows is simply unable to show more! Would it be possible to have less nesting structure inside lodash?

title: Problem chaining head and rest with nested array
body:
``` js
_([ [1, 2], [3, 4] ]).head().valueOf() // [1, 2]
_([ [1, 2], [3, 4] ]).head().rest(); // TypeError: undefined is not a function
```

title: Suggestion: add _.demethodize(...) method
body: I'd suggest adding a `_.demethodize(...)` method, to transform a method into a generic function, as in http://tech.pro/blog/2097/clever-way-to-demethodize-native-js-methods, https://www.npmjs.com/package/demethodize, and http://tech.pro/tutorial/2010/functional-javascript-part-3-apply-call-and-the-arguments-object

title: Default the `thisArg` value for iteration callbacks to the element
body:
The `thisArg` is optional for iteration/collection methods. It would improve the flexibility of the collections API if the thisArg were defaulted to the current-iteration element. This would allow:

`_.each(coll, myFunc)` where `myFunc` needs to be executed as `myFunc.apply(coll[x])`

Presently this must be accomplished via:

`_.each(coll, _.bind(myFunc.apply, myFunc))`

And is especially helpful with bound args

`_.each(coll, _.partialRight(myFunc, args))`
vs
`_.each(coll, _.partialRight(_.bind(myFunc.apply, myFunc), args))`

title: _.assign doc seems wrong
body:
The signature for [`_.assign()`](https://lodash.com/docs#assign) is:

> `_.assign(object, [source], [callback], [thisArg])`

The doc says:

> Assigns own enumerable properties of source object(s) to the destination object.

The doc example shows:

``` javascript
var object = { 'name': 'barney' };
defaults(object, { 'name': 'fred', 'employer': 'slate' });
// â†’ { 'name': 'barney', 'employer': 'slate' }
```

Problems:
1. The doc speaks of "destination", the signature only has "object". It is not clear enough for an API doc. (And this is the case for many other methods)
2. If I am right in thinking that "object" is the "destination", then: assigning from source to destination means that properties of "destination" should be overwritten by properties of "source". But in the example it shows the opposite: the returned object has `name:"barney"` which has not been overwritten by the source object.
3. TODO: check what happens if there are more than 1 source: the doc says that "Subsequent sources will overwrite property assignments of previous sources." Is this correct ?

Side node:

I see that the `_.assign()` has an alias: `_.extend()`. If this is for people familiar with jQuery, you should remove it, because it works in the opposite way than `jQuery.extend()`.

Edit:

right, i just noticed that in the "Arguments list" it is specified that the "object" is the destination object. Sorry, I should have read better. But maybe if we could change "object" to "destination" in the signature it would be more clear ? My question is: why do you name the first argument "object" and the second "source" ? Why not naming both "object" ? or the first "destination" and the second "source" ?

title: Why is there no `whereKey`?
body:
I have a piece of code that uses underscore's `where` to return all values that match certain properties, however because I actually wanted to return the key, I decided to try out lodash as I saw it has a `findKey` method. However I discovered that there's no `whereKey`, which I would image to return an array of keys appropriate to the search- or an empty array, much in the same way as _'s native where.

I'm happy to look into doing a PR for `whereKey`, `whereIndex`, `findWhereKey`, `findWhereIndex`, etc if there're no huge arguments against it.

Thanks
Maff

title: Arity of curried function not taken into account when multiple values provided
body:
The following example shows a bug where setting the arity of the curried function does not prevent the function from using more then that number of arguments.

Here I create a curried function of arity two which allows me to have a set of things and then keep checking if an item is in it.  This is needed since `_.contains` provides a third argument of a starting index which I need to avoid if I want my function to work as part of a `_.filter` or other such method which provides more then a single argument to the callback

**bug** Example

``` javascript
_.curry(_.contains, 2)([1,3,5])(1)
// -> true
_.curry(_.contains, 2)([1,3,5])(1, 2)
// -> false
```

**usage** Example

``` javascript
_.filter(some_items, _.curry(_.contains, 2)(allowed_items));
```

I tried using `_.partial` but this also has the third argument issue and there it makes more sense, IMO.

title: Enhancement: Mongodb like filtering
wishlist: flatMap
body:
Something I use a lot in ruby is [flat_map](http://apidock.com/ruby/Enumerable/flat_map) its equivalent to `_.flatten(_.map(` what makes flatMap especially useful is it can be chained down layers of object hierarchy.

Use case Examples:
- You have a list of boxes that each have a list of items in that box. Your UX wants to show a list of items.
- You have a list of adoption centers, centers have list of adoption records, adoption records list the pet owners. You want to know all pet owners across all centers. flatMap twice, then uniq.

title: Provide example for using lodash.compat with Browserify or publish lodash-compat?
body:
If someone is using something like Browserify, and they need to support older browsers they'll probably want to use the compat version of lodash, but there's no examples of this usage.

I propose adding something like this to the installation instructions:

``` javascript
var _ = require('lodash/dist/lodash.compat.js');
```

Another alternative would be to publish `lodash-compat`.  I think it would make sense, since `lodash-underscore` is already published. The downside would be that it's yet another thing to maintain :(.

title: _.property with nested properties
_.findIndex returns -1 for an object key with value 0
body:
When looking for a particular object key in an array, the index is returned as -1 if the value is 0.

``` js
var objs = [{'a': 1}, {'b': 0}],
    index = _.findIndex(objs, 'b');

console.log(index); // -1
```

It is very much possible to have values as 0, for example in an application which deals with numbers.

title: Make `thisArg` callable, at least in `map`
body:
Hello,

I'd like to bind `this` "dynamically" when `map`-ping a function on an array :

There is some code to illustrate this:

```
o = {bar: 42, foo: function () { return this.bar; }};
a = [o, o];
_.map(a, function (e) { return e.bar; }) // output: [ 42, 42 ] - OK
_.map(a, o.foo) // output: [ undefined, undefined ] - KO
_.map(a, o.foo, function () { return this; }) // same output
_.map(a, o.foo, function () { console.log('thisArg called'); }) // same output, with nothing printed
```

Of course, `foo` could be any function, not necessarily an accessor.

Btw, is there a shorthand for `function () { return this; }` ?

[].forEach.call(null, function(){}) // throw Error

body:
I wonder if it makes sense to mutate wrapped arrays. Do you see any use-cases for e.g. mutating `reverse`? My assumption is that `arr.reverse()` should be preferred over `_(arr).reverse();`.

Note that currently:
`_(hugeArray).reverse().filter(...).map(...).filter(...).take(5).value()` will perform native `reverse` rather than lazy one, which is wrong in this scenario.

title: Fix broken lazy reverse
body: Lazy `reverse` was never called. E.g. here: `_(arr).map().reverse()` normal `reverse` was called, breaking a lazy chain.

> _.take(_.range(0.0,10.1,0.1), 10)

title: Update doc comment for intersection
body: sort order is preserved if the sorted array is first, cf. https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/779#issuecomment-63075778

title: _.filter called on an object doesn't provide keys to the callback
body:
I'm trying to use _.filter to filter a collection based on it's keys. The documentation suggests that the second argument passed to the callback will be index if an array, otherwise the key. 

Here is a basic test use case: `_.filter({a:1}, function (){console.log(arguments)})`

In lodash (2.4.1) the log is: `[1, 0]`

In underscore.js the log is: `[1, "a", Object]` (which I expect).

title: Does _.intersection guarantee sort order?
body:
For this code:

```
var included_sorted_items_array = _.intersection(sorted_items_array, included_items_array);
```

I want to know if the order of the items in the result (if any) is guaranteed to match the order of the "sorted_items_array". It appears to be so with a quick experiment, but the docs don't make a statement about sort order.

title: Cannot use wrapped collection as _.difference() parameter
Implement lazy `_().pluck` and `_().where`
body: `_(arr).pluck(key)` shall be lazy

title: _.pick and _.omit do not support callback
body:
Seen on both lo-dash v2.4.1 and v1.2.1 underscore builds.

Both _.pick and _.omit state in the documentation (and source code comments) that a callback can be provided to pick key value pairs. On inspection however this appears not to be the case:

``` js
_.pick({ 'name': 'fred', '_userid': 'fred1' }, function(value, key) {return key.charAt(0) != '_';})
expected:
=> { name: 'fred' }
actual:
=> {}

_.omit({ 'name': 'fred', '_userid': 'fred1' }, function(value, key) {return key.charAt(0) != '_';})
expected:
=> { _userid: 'fred1' }
actual:
=> { name: 'fred', _userid: 'fred1' }
```

title: Binding to native callback provokes TypeError
body:
I'm trying to directly use a native function as a callback and binding it via `thisArg` but in the following case a `TypeError` is triggered whereas when the native function is bound explicitly via `bind()` it does work:

```
var _ = require('lodash');
var assert = require('assert');

var a = [
  /foo/,
  /bar/
];
var t = 'bar';

// these work
assert.equal(_.some(a, String.prototype.match.bind(t), t), true);
assert.equal(_.some(a, String.prototype.match.bind(t)), true);

// should be equivalent but throws 'TypeError: String.prototype.match called on null or undefined'
assert.equal(_.some(a, String.prototype.match, t), true);
```

(also available at https://gist.github.com/akloeber/b09a174e4dd7737b66e8)

This leads to the following stacktrace:

```
.../node_modules/lodash/dist/lodash.js:3955
          if ((result = callback(collection[index], index, collection))) {
                        ^
TypeError: String.prototype.match called on null or undefined
    at match (native)
    at Function.some (/Users/aske/Repos/tr8/node_modules/lodash/dist/lodash.js:3955:25)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/aske/Repos/tr8/lodash.bug.js:15:16)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:497:10)
    at startup (node.js:119:16)
    at node.js:906:3
```

**Environment:**
lodash 2.4.1
node.js 0.10.33
Mac OS X 10.10
I see that we're at 3.0.0-pre, but it seems like it's been that way for a while, and I can't find any milestones about it. Any progress updates?

title: Use _.identity as default wrapper function for _.wrap
body: I often have the need to wrap a value in a function especially when working with angular's resolve mechanism. This change shouldn't break anything and would be a useful default.

title: Feature request: #getProp, #setProp with 'dot notation'.
merge overwrites source object
body:
On terms of intuitive bearing of other functionally oriented libraries, merge blitzing the 'source' object is very odd.

``` javascript
var a = {a: 1, b: 2},
    b = {b: 10, c: 20};

_.merge(a,b); // => {a: 1, b: 10, c: 20} Looks good!

console.log(a); // Object {a: 1, b: 10, c: 20} ....why?
```

I realize you can do this:

``` javascript
_.merge({}, a, b);
```

....but that's seriously off to me at least. That's not something I'd be expecting when using the merge function, I'd expect a new object instead to which if I wanted to override I'd do:

``` javascript
a = _.merge(a,b);
```

In terms of chaining or functional style, this can make for a nasty little speed bump to some despite being in the documentation.

title: Merge getter
Release func in _.before and _.once
body:
`func` isn't released until the _before_ function is called n times, when it's possible to release it after n-1 times. Since `_.once` uses `_.before`, this means that a _onced_ function isn't released until the 2nd time you call it.

(submitted a CLA on 2014-10-18 19:38:02)

title: Extend _.has to support multiple keys
body:
Hey @jdalton , how would you feel about extending `_.has()` to support checking if an `Object` contains multiple keys, e.g.

``` js
var obj = { foo: 'a', bar: 'b', baz: 'c' };

_.has(obj, ['foo', 'baz']) // true
_.has(obj, ['foo', 'not_there']) // false
```

Thanks
:smile:

title: Allow for _.bind to accept either a string or a function
body:
Hi there,
I understand that bindKey supports this behavior, however, it would be nice to not have to pick and choose when to use one or the other.
My proposal is to allow a method signature for `_.bind` like the following two options:

```
_.bind(console.log, console, [args])
```

or

```
_.bind('log', console, [args])
```

The reason for this is 1. it's nice sugar, but 2. in the context of my first request here: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/748 then it seems like it would be nice to just do `_.bind` and `_.bindRight` than to have 4 total functions `_.bind`, `_.bindRight`, `_.bindKey` and `_.bindKeyRight`.

I don't know if this is something you'd consider adding, but looking forward to hearing your thoughts.

Thanks!

title: Full control over merge
body:
I would like to have access to objects/arrays owning property as well as a property name.
Additionally I would like to be able to return undefined as a merged value. Perhaps by returning some special object, e.g. `_.explicitUndefined`.

title: merge breaks with readonly properties on phantomjs
body:
There is a bug in phantomjs ariya/phantomjs#10889 that causes lodash to run in strict mode and uncovers bug in lodash where it will overwrite readonly property and fail.

At the end of [baseMerge](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/2.4.1/lodash.js#L1568) there is an unconditional assignment:

```
object[key] = value;
```

This needs to test whether `object[key] !== value` which would avoid at least some problems.
Properties with getters should probably be skipped altogether, but maybe some control over that can be given to user via callbacks.

Also, why are you not using `use strict` in lodash ?

title: Wrong return value of _.min with Infinity
Lodash Build Tool Documentation is Incorrect
body:
The Lodash custom build tool claims that:

> All commands except `backbone`, `legacy`, `mobile`, `modern`, & `underscore` may be combined.

However, if you try to combine the `underscore` option with the `compat` option, the tool informs you that:

> The `compat` and `underscore` commands may not be combined.
> For more information type: lodash --help

It seems that `compat` should be added to the list of options that can't be combined.

Also, is there any way to build a version of Lodash that includes both IE8 compatability _and_ Underscore support?  The whole reason I'm switching to Lodash is because of its excellent IE8 support (unlike Underscore), but unfortunately I already have a codebase with 1000+ instances of  code that expects chaining to work the Underscore way, not the Lodash way (ie. I have a ton of `_(foo).bar()`).

If there is any way to create such a build it would be extremely helpful.  Thanks.

title: Templates within templates
body:
Is it possible to render a template like:

```
<%%=  FOO %>
```

which results in:

```
<%= FOO %>
```

?

This is supported by ERB and used to make templates that generate templates.  For example, Ruby on Rails's scaffolding requires this feature. Or, it can be used to have a template show the delimiters without having to change them. 

Thoughts about making _.template support something like this?

title: Add an `_.isPromise` function
body:
This PR adds the `_.isPromise` function that returns a boolean which indicates if the argument is a `Promise` object, per the [Promises A+ spec](https://promisesaplus.com/).

`_.isPromise({}); // => false`
`_.isPromise({then: function () {}}); // => true`
`_.isPromise(function () {}); // => false`

Since different libraries implement promises differently, this is the truest way to check whether a value is a promise object.

title: Source URLs not working in templates
body: Using both chrome canary and chrome beta, my source URLs from `_.template` are no longer working. Sample expression: ``` _.template('Foo', null, {sourceURL: '/template/foo'}); ``` Expected result: - The `/template/foo` script shows up in the list of scripts in Chrome dev tools Actual result: - The `/template/foo` script does not show up in the list of scripts in Chrome dev tools I've tracked this down to the definition of sourceURL in lodash.js. Currently, the `sourceURL` line is wrapped in a multi-line comment, like this: ``` /* //# sourceURL=/template/foo */ ``` If I remove the multi-line comment, the source urls work again, and the templates show up as scripts in the dev tools: ``` //# sourceURL=/template/foo ```

title: ES6 iterables
body: ES6 provides a number of datastructures that are [iterable](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/iterable). It would be nice if lodash supported these.

title: [Feature Request] _.callWith
